properties.Title: Covid-19 Nova Scotia State Of Emergency
properties.Summary:
Description: COVID-19 is deadly. Stop the spread now. STAY HOME. Only leave for essential groceries, prescriptions or medical appointments. Ignoring public health direction endangers lives. STAY HOME. Protect yourself and others. novascotia.ca/coronavirus
Expires: 2020-04-11T10:45:00-03:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Nova Scotia Emergency Management Office, 2020-04-10T11:00:36-03:00, 8CE9126A-B702-99E5-9A0B-A6DF48E3D6E5
Area: Nova Scotia
properties.Author: Nova Scotia Emergency Management Office

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall amounts of 25 to 35 centimetres are expected over these regions. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-11T00:23:51-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rapidly accumulating snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: near 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 50 km/h, except 70 along parts of the coast. Locations: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay. Time span: late this afternoon until just after midnight. Remarks: Snow will begin late this afternoon and accumulate quickly through the evening hours. Gusty winds accompanying the snow will cause reduced visibilities at times in blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-04-11T05:43:18-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels along the coast. Time span for storm surge: within 2 hours of noon. High tide: peaking near noon today. Remarks: Very low pressure will coincide with very large spring tides to produce significantly elevated water levels. This may produce some minor flooding, especially along shorelines exposed to the east. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 150 km/h until early this afternoon. Location: Wreckhouse area. ### Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at high risk of being overturned. Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds with damaging wind gusts are expected or occurring. Location: from Margaree Harbour to Bay St. Lawrence. Time span: this morning. Maximum gusts: 140 km/h. Very strong easterly winds will continue in the lee of the Highlands this morning. Wind gusts will likely reach 140 km/h later this morning before diminishing around midday today. ### Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at high risk of being overturned. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-10T19:19:04-00:00

Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly 100 km/h except up to 120 km/h in the Port aux Basques area. Locations: south, east, and northeast coasts of Newfoundland. Time span: until this afternoon for the south coast and this afternoon into early this evening for the east and northeast coasts. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warning of potential breaking sea and coastal flood conditions issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec region on 2020-04-09. An intense low pressure system is producing strong winds in the areas listed below. The combination of these winds and the current run of high-amplitude tides could produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast near the following locales on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Daylight Time). Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2020-04-10, from 04:00 PM to 08:00 PM. Matane: 2020-04-10, from 04:00 PM to 08:00 PM. Sainte-Anne-des-Monts - Grande-Vallée: 2020-04-10, from 04:00 PM to 08:00 PM. Forillon Park - Gaspé - Percé: 2020-04-10, from 04:00 PM to 08:00 PM. New-Carlisle - Chandler: 2020-04-10, from 04:30 PM to 08:30 PM. ### High waves combined with the surge may cause damage along the coast. Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-11T02:29:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-10T15:16:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0857006223.2020
Area: Mont-Joli area, Le Bic - Rimouski area, Matane, Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area, Chandler area, New Carlisle - Port-Daniel area, Forillon National Park - Gaspé area, Percé area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Storm surge warning Warning of potential coastal flood conditions issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec area on the 2020-04-09. An intense low pressure system is producing very strong winds in the areas listed below. The combination of these winds and the fact that we are currently in a period of high tidal range could produce coastal flooding along the coast near these localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Daylight Time). Quebec City: 2020-04-10, from 07:30 PM to 10:30 PM. ### Coastal flooding is possible along the shoreline. Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-11T04:44:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-10T15:16:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1500020579.2020

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 25 mm. Locations: southern Avalon Peninsula. Time span: this afternoon. Remarks: Snow or ice pellets this morning will change to rain near noon. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-04-10T23:59:51-00:00

Area: Avalon Peninsula Southeast, Avalon Peninsula Southwest

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. 25 to 35 centimetres of snow, strong northeast winds and blowing snow until this evening. A major storm is expected to move over the Maritimes and the Gulf of St Lawrence today. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-11T07:04:30-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels are expected today. Locations: Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia. Time span: during high tide this morning and early this afternoon. The combination of storm surge from a passing low pressure system and strong winds will create higher than normal water levels and rough and pounding surf this morning during high tide. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds with severe and damaging gusts are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: easterly 90 km/h, except locally 120 km/h in areas prone to enhanced easterlies. Locations: western Newfoundland. Time span: until this afternoon. Remarks: Local enhancement in easterly flow typically occurs in the vicinities of Cape St. George, Port au Port Bay, the outer Bay of Islands, Trout River Bay, Bonne Bay, Western Brook Pond and St. Pauls Bay. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Brief rain showers transitioning to periods of snow early this morning will spread southward from the northern Alberta foothills, to the international border by this afternoon. The snow will intensify late in the afternoon and, become heavy at times tonight. Snowfall will start to abate from north to south Saturday morning, with total accumulations of 10 to 20 cm expected. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-11T02:34:40-00:00

properties.Summary:

High water level warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in blowing snow and rapidly accumulating snowfall are expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 70 km/h, except 90 along parts of the coast. Locations: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair. Time span: this afternoon until this evening. Remarks: Snow will begin this afternoon and accumulate quickly until tapering to flurries this evening. Strong winds will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause blowing snow creating near-zero visibilities. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-04-11T03:29:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-10T13:44:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0825140392.2020
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall and high winds are expected. Further snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 90 km/h. Locations: Acadian Peninsula Time span: today Remarks: snow heavy at times will continue this afternoon and into the early part of the event. Very strong winds will continue into the afternoon giving reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow. Conditions will gradually improve tonight as the system departs. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, rain and wind is expected today. Locations: central and northern Newfoundland. Maximum wind gusts: east to southeasterly 80 km/h, possibly higher over exposed areas of central Newfoundland. Time span: late this morning into this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
